sections.1_story_intuition: The Indian Freedom Movement was a long and determined struggle to end British colonial rule in India. It involved mass movements, key leaders, and landmark events that shaped the nation's destiny. This topic is frequently asked in competitive exams, covering important dates, personalities, and milestones in India's path to independence.
2_key_definitions: Freedom Movement: Collective efforts to achieve independence from foreign rule.
Satyagraha: Non-violent resistance led by Mahatma Gandhi.
Swadeshi: Use of Indian-made goods to boycott British products.
Civil Disobedience: Refusal to obey unjust laws.
Quit India Movement: 1942 mass protest demanding British exit.
Partition: Division of India and Pakistan in 1947.
Revolutionary: Person using radical means for freedom.
INC: Indian National Congress, main political party.
Simon Commission: British committee without Indian members.
Dandi March: 1930 salt protest led by Gandhi.
3_key_facts_data_points: INA (Azad Hind Fauj) led by Subhas Chandra Bose.
Key leaders: Gandhi, Nehru, Patel, Bose, Tilak.
5_exam_capsules: When was the First War of Independence? 1857.
What happened in 1919? Jallianwala Bagh Massacre.
Who led Dandi March? Mahatma Gandhi.
Who led INA? Subhas Chandra Bose.
When did India gain independence? 15 August 1947.
Who was the first PM of India? Jawaharlal Nehru.
What was the Poona Pact? Agreement on Dalit representation.
What was the Rowlatt Act? Repressive law, 1919.
Who were key revolutionaries? Bhagat Singh, Azad.
What was the Khilafat Movement? Muslim protest, 1919-24.
What was the Cabinet Mission? 1946 plan for transfer of power.
What was the Mountbatten Plan? Partition proposal, 1947.
Who was Sardar Patel? Iron Man of India.
7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up Dandi March and Quit India.
Assuming all revolutionaries were from Bengal.
Confusing Poona Pact and Cabinet Mission.
Mixing up Partition and Independence dates.

8_case_study_context.title: Dandi March: Salt Satyagraha
8_case_study_context.explanation: The Dandi March of 1930, led by Mahatma Gandhi, was a non-violent protest against the British salt tax. It marked a turning point in the freedom movement and inspired mass participation across India.
